San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMO.name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA)

address.streetAddress: 151 3rd St Enter on Howard or Third Street

reviews: we arrived late so unable to visit all floors, but the Bend collection of latin art on main floor worth seeing. They had the Rauschenberg show but I really can say I don't like his work at all. But that's my taste.......
Worth a look, but if you are not enthralled by modern art, it might not be for you. Also, if you are a MOMA regular, you could be somewhat let down.

Loved seeing the Warhols and Lichtensteins. Wouls like to see more! Interesting exhibits and my 3 kids under age 12 were interested and loved the gft shop. Outstanding collections on many floors. Many artist you will recognize. Nice restaurants and gift shops. Put in on your most stop.
Contemporary Art Collection Outstanding-New Wing and Interiors Disappointing

The entrance experience has lost some of its drama in the expanded Museum. Orientation is overly complicated with too many dead end galleries. Elevators very slow; should have been electric traction. People are annoyed when waiting several minutes to move between floors. Gift shop at street level is well worth walking through with no entry fees. New specialty restaurant at street level pricey and not as inviting as the former cafeteria. Special exhibitions excellent.

After long renovation period, San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA) is one of the best museums of modern art in the States. Beautiful building, interesting exhibitions and cool museum store. You need at least a few hours to visit all the floors and I highly recommend visiting this place more than once. It's a paradise for modern art enthusiasts. There are permanent pieces in their collection, as well as new expanding collections. The last floor was closed during my visit, which was a bit disappointing, but they need time to arrange a new exhibition. Another reason to visit SFMOMA at least a few times. Every visit is a new adventure!

Always a wonderful new exhibition to see!

I managed to get to the museum before the Rauschenberg exhibit closed. It's an exquisite exhibition that really shows who this man was ie., a force of creative nature. He worked in so many media: painting, found objects, set design, photography, you name it. By the way, there is always a fabulous photography exhibit. I try to get to the museum every few months. Tip: great restaurants there. And book store.

My Favorite of San Francisco's Museums

I've been visiting the SFMoMA as far back as when it used to be at the War Memorial Theater and later to its new incarnation in the 1990s on 3rd Street and its even newer expansion in 2016. I love it most for its permanent collection with works from Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera, Roy Lichtenstein, Gerhard Richter, Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Josef Albers, Alexander Calder, Robert Indiana and so many more iconic paintings and photographs and sculptures. I'll keep going back because I think it's the one most vibrant and relevant art scenes, and there aren't enough hours in a day to take it all in.

This is a well-designed building with a small permanent collection and several floors of rotating collections of modern art. The real strengths are in the special exhibits. There are several seemingly fine cafes throughout the museum. Avoid the floor-level "exhibit-cafe" in situ. It's a poor excuse for either an exhibit or restaurant.

We only had a couple of hours, so focused only on two floors - 2 and 5. We had a few wow moments! Great collection, carefully curated and displayed, and with just enough detailed information to help us understand some background on the pieces and artists. Kids were free, which is a great sign that a gallery values its community. Their favorite part was the sculpture on floor 1. Loved our visit, look forward to going back and seeing more.

Good but a bit disappointing as 2 exhibitions were closed

It was nice but it was a bit disappointing as 2 exhibitions were closed. We actually came to see photography floor which was closed completely. The rest was very good. 2nd floor has good collections. Museum has good presentation of American artists.

The MOMA for us did not get the must visit it deserves .. it is definitely worth a visit

It’s close to town and a easy walk from union square
The art is as expected a good combination of new and modern and its set out in a very good way .. there is also a good cafe shop !!!

Simply a great place to see some stellar modern work, with sound, electricity, and some very cool exhibits around the tech of our age. There are seven levels and it's good thing they ask you to start on level 7 with the sound exhibits. Then you can enjoy your way down through all the displays down. I spent about 4 hours here and couldn't see all of the museum's work.
Get there early or buy a ticket online to skip the lines. The museum store t ground level has some nice science toys for kids.

Great Collections of Modern and Contemporary Art

This was our first visit since the new building was completed. The premises were expanded to accommodate the spectacular Fisher collection, the museum's own expanding collection and for exhibition space. We believe the completed building project to be an unqualified success and the airy galleries add to the delight of viewing the important works on display. We spent two days at the museum rather than the one we had planned. Additionally, there are three separate areas to eat, a good coffee/tea bar, a world class cafe (where we enjoyed two lunches) and a fine dining restaurant which we did not have the opportunity to sample. Aside from the art and the dining we appreciated a free group tour of one of the temporary exhibits led by a knowledgeable guide. Finally the gift shop offers many unique items as well as lots of interesting books about art.

Excellent Museum in the Heart of the City
An excellent museum, very convenient to visit. Wish we had more time to explore the extensive collection and special exhibitions! Especially enjoyed the Robert Rauschenberg retrospective!

This was my first visit there since they completed their major renovation. It's much, much bigger than it used to be. The building itself is a work of art. Many beautiful spaces to just sit and linger both indoors and out. Highly recommend it.

I love to always visit a Museum on the Big City’s and this time it was the time for SF MoMa is amazing all the Vision that this modern artist have. From the gigantic Spiders to the relaxing sound creat by porcelain pots; from the upside down drum to a one color paint; is really a nice experience; don’t forget and always open tour eyes to ART

Everyone needs a bit of LOVE

What is art? Although some of the works shown at the SFMOMA may make you question the concept, they are all accessible and well curated. The museum itself is beautiful from both the inside and out. A visit outdoors to the various outdoor sculpture areas is a must. Best is that the museum participates in reciprocal relationships with museums from around the country, making it accessible to visitors who might otherwise question the steep price tag.

Nothing very notable given the dominance of this museum in the SF art scene - Legion of Honor Museum was more interesting. It seemed cold and the security very prominent. The museum of Modern Art is spacious, pleasant and well curated. My kids (11 and 9 years old) enjoyed it as well as my husband and I. We spent about 5 hours there, each floor has different exhibits - photos, works of art, music and sounds.

The building itself is art. There are 7 floors including outdoor spaces. Many different types of art on display. The music installations on the top floor were just breathtaking and so innovative. So glad I stopped by.

SFMOMA, since its added galleries, thanks to the Fisher family, sports some of the best contemporary and modern art in the country. Both the Fisher collection plus all the other art and significant exhibitions are a must for anyone interested in this art. Vistors to San Francisco should put this on top of their list. Note that you can't use someone else's museum card because they check ID when you go to the ticket counter. Shop is excellent with books, jewelry and other great objects. Good restaurant in the museum. Beautiful views of the city while walking around the galleries. Parking is easy and within a block of the museum.

Put a little culture in your life. Seven floors of fun to open the mind and heart. Its a nice way to see what happening and people what. The free tours are every interesting.

Personally I prefer the MoMA in New York but the Chuck Close mosaic like portraits are mind blowing - view them from a distance and then gradually walk closer and closer to see how the portrait is built up from abstract circles and shapes separately coloured which transform in to a near perfect likeness of whomever he has painted.

Really enjoyed my time here but the tickets were pricey. They had famous artist's work there and some interactive exhibits.

Not our first visit, and most likely not our last...

Somehow this was not nearly as exciting as MOMA in NY and a couple of hours there was more than enough. I would not visit again unless there was a particularly interesting display coming to town.

The majority of the art is quite modern, clearly true to the name San Francisco Museum of MODERN art. I love walking through this museum and getting lost for hours. The structure of the building is beautiful, meditative and relatively newly renovated. Each floor has a brilliant collection of photography and modern art as well as interactive displays.

One of my favorite parts of the museum is the very top with a noise instrument type display with video art on all three walls. I can't recall the name of it but if you are there in the next few months, please visit and make it to the top.

The museum alternates exhibitions often, but every time I visit, about once per year; I am pleasantly surprised at the quality of work and precision in the display. Highly recommend.

A visit to this museum could easily fill a day. After lunch elsewhere with friends we arrived about 1pm and headed to the 5th floor to work our way down. We took our time on each floor and were not able to see all the exhibits. I enjoyed walking outside and viewing the City from atop. I am more of a traditionalist when it comes to art, but this museum was fun to visit with so many different forms of visualization and sounds. It truly amazed me to think of how much work goes in to changing out the art for new exhibits. I would visit again and allow more time.

SF Moma gets interesting every floor. You can go up to the fifth floor down to the first or go the other way around. So much art to see and appreciate!
The only thing I don't like is expensive parking fee. But it's SF, so I shouldn't complain much. Public transit is always a viable option too. You can easily spend half a day or a full day at SFMOMA.
A bit pricey but worth visiting
Place was packed on a Saturday afternoon. Not too much modern art but some exhibits were interesting. I especially loved ‘the visitors’.
We spent the day at the museum and were able to experience all seven floors. The art was diverse and interesting.
Overpriced, not family friendly, not worth it

I was very excited to check out the MOMA after its recent renovation. I was underwhelmed. For starters, I was hoping to spend some time on my own wandering around the museum, but when I called, they were unapologetic about being unable to offer anywhere to pump. Thankfully, I was able to drag the entire family so that I could go (and breastfeed when needed).

When we walked in, the temperature was suffocating. I don't know if they were trying to compensate for the cold outside, but it was horrible. The lines to get tickets, even in the membership line, were also long and slow.

A couple of the exhibits themselves were interesting, but I thought it was lame that they are rotating political posters in phases (please, come spend more money so you can see the other ones!). Most of the exhibits were just OK, and none were really interactive. Needless to say, this is NOT a kid-friendly museum.

Finally, the cafe was absurdly overpriced. For $15, the least you can do is add a little salad to the small and sparse sandwich. And my daughter's meal was about a half a teaspoon each of peanut butter and jelly on 2 Hawaiian rolls. For $7.50. I spent more here for less food than I have ever spent at any museum or zoo, and we were all still hungry!

There are so many great museums in SF. I'll go to them.

This museum occupies seven floors with a many different exhibits on each one. The second floor is a photography exhibit with photos from around the world dating back over a hundred years. It was great learning the evolution of photography. Other floors had paintings of all types. One are had pictures of people. When you got close, you could see that the pictures were composed of many small shapes. There was a musical floor where there were musical contraptions that were fascinating to watch and listen to. We were entranced by the exhibit on the top floor that had a round pool of water that had many bowls of different size. The water had jets that caused the water to move. This caused the bowls to gently bang into each other creating a relaxing melody. We spent most of the day there and could have stayed longer if time permitted.

We had a great time exploring this museum today! (It helped that instead of paying the $25 adult admission price, we had free tickets.) We explored all of it, enjoyed much of it, and especially appreciated the soundscape exhibits. There's so much mindfood in here!

This place is huge and the building itself is so interesting. I only had a few hours and you really need more and multiple visits to do it justice, Although at $25 a visit, that may not be practical. There is a huge variety of styles and genres exhibited here; from quite early modern art including impressionists and people like Braque, Picasso, Klee, Mondrian up to brand new installation art. At present on the 7th floor there is a remarkable exhibition which focuses on sound made by art objects. My favourite is a large pool on which are randomly floating plain white china bowls of varying sizes. They clinking and tinkling as they lazily make their various ways through shallow blue pond. It is aurally and visually calming. Lovely.There is a coat check on the ground floor and it may pay to leave your bag as the gallery insists that bags are carried to the front of you so you don't bang into anyone or anything - it's a pain. On the upside - you are welcome to take non flash photos.

one of the great museum experiences

Following a three-year closure and an expansive (and expensive) enlargement and restoration, SFMOMA reopened in 2016 as the country’s largest modern art museum, exceeding even New York’s MOMA. The museum collection includes top-notch examples in every field of contemporary art; the seven floors can be quite daunting, so it’s best to do a little homework and focus on one or two areas of interest. The temporary exhibitions (which at the time of writing include world-class retrospectives of Walker Evans and Robert Rauschenberg) set a gold standard in comprehensiveness. Best of all, the museum’s top floor is devoted to large-scale installations, at which SFMOMA has always excelled. Whatever your interests, it’s worth starting there for a glimpse at some of the most innovative art on display anywhere.

Love art. Liked the museum. You could honestly do this in a few hours or stretch it out and take a few days. I’d recommend as many guided tours as you can stand. (I usually move at a faster tempo than most so I could only do so many)

We only stay at museums and art galleries for an hour or two (as my head gets full), but the SF MOMA visit was different. Everyone was so helpful, the art was wonderful and the special exhibits were spectacular - we stayed for hours!

I have been to this museum several times, but this is the first time I have been since the building reopened after remodeling. They did a beautiful job and there is so much more space for things. For some odd reason, a lot of the permanent collection is now hidden away on the second floor -you have to actively search it out. Louise Bourgeois' Spider sculptures have a stunning new room - don’t miss the oculus bridge. Also, don’t miss the giant Richard Serra sculpture accessed from stairs on the second floor. Lots to see.

Excellent Musem showcasing high quality Modern Art
For the Bay Area, the SF MOMA matches the brilliance of Silicon Valley with an incredible display of art reflecting the times we live and presenting the most exiting modern artists.
Awesome collection of modern art from around the world and across time periods.

Don't miss the Paul Klee Gallery, with its many Matisse works, and the German Art after 1960 Gallery (a lot of impressive Kiefer, Richter and Polke works). And there is always a wonderful special exhibition.

I love checking out art museums in the cities I visit. Being an old deadhead I’ve done quite a bit of traveling over the past few decades following that band and every chance I get I check out the art museums in whatever city I’m in. This MOMA truly lives up to its name. It’s pretty strictly modern art and it’s collection is fabulous. Well represented contemporary collection with the greats of modern art Warhol, Calder, Lichtenstein, Still. And many other lesser known but equally talented artists. The floor space is open and airy. The building itself has multiple floors and each floor has top quality representation of the artists in their collection. Not only did I like it my teenage daughter did as well and that was a surprise. In fact she ended up doing all the floors which totally shocked me. The outdoor sculpture gardens were great. Nice place to get a little air and sit down to rest. There is an elevator but it’s slow and the stairs may be a bit arduous for some people. It’s probably better to try to do this museum over two days but often that’s not practical. There’s a small cafe area for coffee. And best of all the gift shop is out of this world. We bought so much we had to have it shipped back home! But awesome stuff which you don’t see in every gift shop and believe me I’m a gift shop girl. I know my gift shops. If you’re in San Fran and you are an art lover this place is a must. If you want to find artsy or unique gifts just stop in the shop. You won’t be disappointed. World class all the way.

Very good museum with modern pieces from different decades. Excellent temporary exhibition on 7th floor dedicated to the connections between sound and the world we leave in. Innovative outside tour to experience the sound of electromagnetic waves in SF.

I had a brief time to explore the museum, and the woman who sold me my ticket gave me a quick overview of the highlights. With her suggestions I saw much of 4 out of the 7 floors and whetted my appetite for a longer exploration in the future.

Along with iconic modern art pieces like Robert Indiana's LOVE, Warhol's Marilyn Monroe graphics, Calder's mobiles, Diego Rivera's and Frida Kahlo's paintings, I was excited to be introduced to many new and international modern artists, and to re-examine Matisse's paintings through a modern art perspective.

Oculus Bridge Takes the Best of Show

After visiting SFMOMA today I did a Google Search for Oculus Bridge listed on their map of the 5th floor. It led me to a photo with the following caption: Photo: “Best view of the oculus with the bridge suspended under it. Taken from lobby. Best musuem feature”

I felt vidicated because as I waited for my wife on the ground floor I looked up and saw it. It was a living Escher whose posters I had on my walls in college. I said to myself "this is probably the best thing I'm going to see all day". I was right. Sure there is some cool stuff there but how many people don't stop in the lobby and look up? Give it some time for some people to wander on the bridge to nowhere, suspended 5 stories above the ground floor (it's a long way down) From below the people appear to be walking in up, down, and sideways, like an Escher. As the caption says "Best museum feature"!!!

I enjoyed my time at MOMA. Okay I went on a Monday morning so it probably wasn't at its busiest but I enjoyed the quite spaces and the atmosphere.

The building itself is a piece of art in itself although to a first time visitor it's not the most straightforward to get around. Each floor is not too large though so there's no chance of getting lost.

The main disappointment about this museum is that, unlike galleries in many cities around the world, you have to pay to enter. I could probably go an about art being free to everyone regardless of their background and wealth, but that's probably one for politicians and not the people who run SFMOMA. Buy a Ticket, Get the App, Enjoy and Excellent Museum

This is an excellent Museum. However a mistake would be to take the offer of a free visit and just see the permanent collection on the second floor, because the upper floors really have some wonders to offer.

There is an excellent App, which you can download free (type in SFMOMA in to the App store and download the red SFMOMA app to avoid the fake version also on offer). The app locates you in the gallery and allows you to bring up brief audio guides on the work that you can see.

The collection is (compared to its New York cousin) relatively small, but high quality with all the big names represented. I was struck by a very interesting Diego Rivera landscape and a magnificent Rothko among others. Also don't miss the little video booth on the way out of the collection. This features short videos and interviews with the artists. Some of these are really beautiful. My favourites were footage of Frida Kahlo and Diego Riviera together in the blue house, an interview with Georgia O'Keefe walking over her favourite hills in New Mexico, an interview with Anselm Kiefer and footage of Warhol completing one of his screen prints.

Going up the floors highlights for me were the Clifford Still works on Level 4, the room of dual portraits on Level 5 and all the Germans on level 6 - especially Keifer and Richter.

Just when you think you have had enough, find some more energy for the seventh floor. Up there you will find some amazing works featuring sound. I found Ragnar Kjartansson's video installation particularly moving. It features nine musicians (including the artist who is singing in the bath) playing together in a decaying mansion in upstate New York. The impact of this work is quite amazing.

Finally, find your way to the cafe and sculpture garden on level 4 (I think) with a gorgeous view of the surrounding buildings.
If you like modern art SFMOMA is a must see destination in San Francisco.

At SF MoMA you could learn, what is art and what is not

Let me start with a simple question: what is the art? How would you define the art without checking Wikipedia?
Leveraging on Coleridge definition of poetry ("the best words in the best order"), I would define the art as the closest approximation to the perfection in the search of harmony and beauty.
This definition gives me ability to differentiate between the master piece and piece of sheet (the typo intended).
Now I could review the SF MoMA. Absolute majority of exhibited artefacts demonstrates that collectors have much more money than good taste or knowledge and understanding of arts.
The permanent collection is a thoughtless waste of millions of dollars on stupid attempts to make something "original" by people who pretend they are artists, but have no talent, gift or ability to paint, draw, or carve.

There are some really great paintings of Henri Matisse, René Magritte, and Willem de Kooning and few other artists.

So the permanent collection doesn't worth to visit. But the SF MoMA had an absolutely fabulous exhibition of Edvard Munch (till Oct 09, 2017).

Nice Museum, Though the Name is a Mis-Nomer, in my Opinion

This is a nice museum, covering 5 floors (6 counting the lobby).

It bills itself as a museum of "modern art", though what I saw was mostly contemporary art. I'm from the East Coast (Boston). Maybe this is how they define modern art on the West Coast, or maybe they're using the term "modern art" in a very general way. I'm thinking of the Museum of Modern Art (New York), Institute of Contemporary Art (Boston), or Mass MOCA. To me, Modern Art encompasses Abstract Expressionism, Surrealism, Cubism, Russian Constructivism, Dadaism, etc, roughly 1900 - 1950. What I saw here was mostly more recent than that. The only exceptions were the Isamu Naguchi exhibit (big Naguchi fan here), and one room of genuine "modern" art on the second floor. In my experience, Contemporary Art includes large installation pieces, video art, all created since about 1960, and that's mostly what I saw here. A good museum, just not "modern art" by the strict definition of the term.

I had lunch at their "Cafe 5". Over-priced (it's a museum, and it's San Francisco), but the best fish sandwich I've ever had.

Visited in August 2017 principally to look at the Pritzker Center for Photography, which was relatively recently opened and touted as "the largest space permanently dedicated to photography in any art museum in the United States", displaying works from a collection of "more than 17,800 photographic works". Incredibly, however, not a single photograph was on display! The whole centre was closed, except the small and poor "hands-on" (really "digital") gallery.

There were also many other gallery closures throughout the museum, with signs saying "Our staff is hard at work on installation of a new exhibition. Please refrain from distracting them with photography or conversation" - hardly welcoming (not a single member of staff in sight). The museum map also was not accurate, as several artists marked on it were no longer on display.

Apart from this, the collection is well worth looking at, with a mixture of very good pieces by the big names of modern art and more regionally-relevant modern artists.

The quality of the food in the usual posh cafe is very high, with a limited but interesting menu, and not too outrageously expensive, at least by normal museum standards. The main store is also amazing.

Failed to find any educational activities in the whole museum, rather incredibly, but my 11-year-old daugher still managed to keep her attention for a couple of hours.

There are no discounts for American Alliance of Museum members, despite the museum being affiliated - very poor form, imho. The entry price is not exactly cheap.

Had an excellent visit to SFMOMA today with my better half during our "hooky day" while traveling for our respective jobs.

We asked the ticketing docent about how much time we should be budgeting, as we were supposed to meet friends after. He asked what our interests were and made excellent suggestions accordingly.

Being a DJ, I found the "Soundtracks" collection on the 7th floor to be a real treat!

Overall the collection is superb. Often collections are repetitive or sparse. Neither is the case here. You can get close enough to see any details you'd want to and pictures are not discouraged.

With the recent expansion, SF MoMA has become an absolute world-class museum in terms of its architecture, permanent collection, and special exhibitions. Just a gorgeous space to see art, and you will not be able to see everything! Too many newly built or renovated museums put architecture before the art but not this one. The architecture is gorgeous, but it is all in the service of art. And art there is, everywhere. There were multiple exhibitions on view, and all were superb. It would take hours to see everything - best to choose a few shows and look at them in depth. I honestly think this museum puts the NY MoMA in a second tier. This is an absolute must see.

Went for a short 1 hour tour with my family. Especially enjoyed the exhibition on the 7th floor which was very interesting..

We came on Sunday at 10:30. The line wasn't bad at all. Adults were $25 each, and kids under 18 are free. We decided to go straight to the Munch exhibit in order to avoid the later-in-the-day crowds. It was very impressive. My seven-year-old and nine-year-old daughters were both very interested in the artist's pieces and his life and struggles. From the Munch exhibit, we decided to head to the cafe for an early lunch. Again, we were really impressed. We all really enjoyed our lunch. I had a fantastic salmon/dill/feta salad, my husband had the shrimp on rye, and my kids opted for the mac and cheese from the kids menu (freshly home made).
After lunch we headed to the 5th floor to see the Warhol collection and thoroughly enjoyed the entire floor of minimalist artwork by various artists.
Finally we decided on heading to the 7th floor and explored all of the sound-related exhibits. We all really enjoyed all of these installations. They were very interactive and really kept my kids' interest.
After the 7th floor, our kids had run out of energy and had reached their fill, so we called it a day. Would love to go back and check out the floors we missed!

Beautiful museum, recently renovated. Take your time to enjoy multiple floors of varied art exhibits. Bright, airy and large enough to give the feeling of space even on a busy summer day. Nice museum store, too.

We were in The City to celebrate our 50th and decided to spend one afternoon at SFMOMA (it had been a while since were visited it). The presence of an exhibit of the work of the Norwegian artist Edvard Munch motivated this choice. We have seen pieces of his work in all the great museums of the world and in 1994 had visited his museum in Oslo. It was a superb exhibit, with work from all stages of his life. And we were not the least upset that The Scream was not among the collection presented. We have seen it on many occasions in other museums. We recommend that visitors to The City take the time to visit SFMOMA.. the building is beautiful and this exhibit very special.

Several years ago I majored in art history at UC Berkeley. My emphasis was on mainly on French Impressionism. When I was a junior in college I enrolled in an art history course - American contemporary art from the 1960s and onwards. One of the assignments of that class was writing a 10-page paper a single piece of painting at the old SF MOMA. I don't recall the name of the painter however I remember the name of the painting "White". That painting had different variations of white with visible brushstrokes. Just imaging writing a 10-page paper on this painting? Yeah it was that difficult especially since I'm not a fan of contemporary art. There was something intriguing about SF MOMA when I was at college. However when I went to the old SF MOMA I felt the layout of museum was dated and unorganized as some of the galleries didn't highlight the exhibition or artwork. Maybe that was why I did like contemporary art. The last time I went to the SF MOMA before it was renovated was in 2007 to see the exhibition "Pablo Picasso in American Art". This was best modern art exhibition I have ever seen because it not only showed Picasso's art but also other American artists that he had influence on.

When the SF MOMA opened after its renovation I wanted to go here especially since the museum is about less than a 10-minute walk from my work. I admit when it comes to visiting a museum it is due to the exhibition. During the Memorial Day Weekend there were two exhibitions that were on the day after Memorial Day - "Monet: The Early Years" at the Legion of Honor and "Matisse/ Diebenkorn" at the SF MOMA. Claude Monet is my favorite painter of all time. I do believe in order expand my repertoire of art appreciation I needed to go to the SF MOMA for that exhibition. Before I decided to go I did some research. I heard about Henri Matisse but not Richard Diebenkorn. I discovered he graduated from Stanford in 1949. That is the reason why I decided to go to the exhibition because as a novice art historian who graduated from Cal I wanted to see works from an artist who graduated from Stanford. I was very glad that I decided to go to the SF MOMA that weekend. From looking at the Diekenborn's paintings you progressions from throughout the works. Even though he graduated from Stanford you see his paintings from his Berkeley series how he interprets the layout of the city. What I liked about this exhibition is you see a painting from Matisse side by side of a painting from Diebenkorn. Even though the paintings are not exact you see how Diebenkorn referred to Matisse when it came to shades of color. The similarities of the paintings would involve the same subject matter however each artist interpreted differently the subject matter such as Henri Matisse's "Woman with a Hat", a painting of Matisse's wife, or Diebenkorn's painting of his wife. Going to the SF MOMA for this exhibition challenged me and I was glad for it.

Working in the Financial District in SF I would pass by the Academy of Art and sometimes noticed some of the artworks. I felt these students would try to become like Picasso with his cubist style. Well to understand how Picasso became Picasso you have to understand what was his influences. If artists who aspire to become Picasso then have to study Diego Velázquez, who Picasso studied a lot from to incorporate his works. For aspiring artists the SF MOMA is a great access as it is downtown SF and is close to Bart. In the future if there are other exhibitions like "Pablo Picasso in American Art" or "Matisse/ Diebenkorn" I say it is a prerequisite for aspiring artists who want to progress because history is influential in art.

There's something for everyone, from sculptures, photography, memorabilia, and some of the finest paintings. Was a bit dubious about paying $25 and then another $6 for the Edvard Munch paintings but so glad I did. Very much worth it. Was expecting two rooms of Munch paintings and was amazed there were almost 50 different paintings in 8(?) rooms! Unlike many other exhibits which are often grouped in a linear manner (e.g. first 10 years, 2nd 20 years, final 15 years) each room had a theme such as "love", "nocturne" and "death/illness" (to paraphrase). It had a much stronger impact as you could see progression as his life changed and as he aged, within a specific theme.

The building itself has always been open and lovely but with the new addition, there is even more open space and room. No matter how many people were in the museum. it did not feel crowded and there was plenty of space to see exhibits from all angles.

The Calder and Warhol galleries are highlights.

There is a some what precious cafe with good coffee and pastries and modern, comfy seating.

By 11:45 am on a Monday, there was quite a line to buy entry tickets so if you are short on time, or just don't like waiting in line to pay, buy tickets in advance online. In fact, you MUST buy advance, timed tickets for the Munch exhibit. The website says there are "limited" tickets available for same day purchase. So don't disappoint yourself and buy tickets for the Munch exhibit in advance if at all possible.

We recently visited the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art for the first time since the reopening and renovation. We bought our tickets in advance online. I'd recommend that if you are not already a member. That way, you can just go in and avoid the ticket lines. We went on a Saturday so it was quite busy. You may HAVE to buy tickets in advance to lock in an arrival/check in time. It seems as thought that's a requirement nowadays.

We went there specifically to see the Edvard Munchen exhibit. We highly recommend this visit and you will have to pay separately. It's worth it. Many of his famous paintings are available for viewing, including "Despair" and "Despair 2". The only odd disappointment is that "Scream" was not part of this exhibit.

But wait, there's more to the museum of course than just the special exhibits. As all great museums, they have continuing and permanent collections of great artists like Alexander Calder, Wayne Thiebaud, and Ellsworth Kelly, Andy Warhol, and special local artists/exhibits like Mike Mandel. There is also a 7th floor exhibit with some unique creations by various artists (very interesting). Check out the suspended upside drum playing and the floating water bowl chimes.

Unfortunately, the only issue was with the audio devices. We've learned over time and visiting other museums that these devices are not seamless in operation. Again, one of our audio players would malfunction and had to be reset. Of course, we would have to go back to the main exhibit entrance to reset. Also, the devices will run low battery. This seems to be an ongoing problem. The audio devices really do add to the education and understanding of the artists and pieces.

When you go please plan on taking your time and plan on enjoying a full day or afternoon. It's worth it.

SFMOMA (So far my only museum article!) - the perfect place to take your Munchkins!

O.K. Call me a Philistine if you will. I live only forty-five minutes from San Francisco, but I can't remember the last time that I made the effort to get from Pleasanton into the city twice in the same week. That changed for the first time in years recently when I was drawn from my East Bay refuge by the Edward Munch exhibit currently showing at SFMOMA. I must admit that part of the attraction was to experience the recently renovated building, but it was the opportunity to view the Munch canvasses that sealed the deal! The SFMOMA is an amazing, bright and airy building in which to display works of art, but the advances in art appreciation that it provides are just as impressive. By accessing their free SFMOMA app on my iPhone, I was able to listen to commentary on a selection of the Munch canvasses, which was vastly superior to simply reading the tiny panels hung on the wall near to each work. I enjoyed myself so much in the Munch exhibit that I continued my exploration of the museum's other floors, discovering to my immense delight an exhibition on Andy Warhol and the Pop Artist movement and many more of my favorites such as, Matisse, Magritte, Dali and more. I took a break for lunch and enjoyed a delicious cheese and charcuterie platter with a glass of Cote de Rhone in the museum restaurant. There is also a coffee shop for those in need of a quick caffeine fix and a pastry. As I wandered through the various floors of the museum, I saw so many parents with their kids pointing out facts about the artist's life and painting style. It occurred to me that a museum like SFMOMA is a pretty cool place to take the kids during summer vacation. They are never too young to develop an appreciation of art and SFMOMA is a perfect museum to start the process.

While primarily visiting the MoMA for the current Edvard Munch exhibit (which was very good albeit a bit depressing and lacking his greatest painting, The Scream), we toured nearly the whole museum. The second floor has a great, somewhat limited Impressionist and Cubist section. Upper floors have modern art and photography with some rather unique structures and paintings. There are four floors in total with plenty of space for viewing. There did not appear to be any prohibitions on photography. There is a cafe in the middle and a peaceful outdoor area with sculptures including several by Calder. Definitely worth a visit to this museum. Entry cost was $25 for adults (discount for those 65 years and older) plus $6 for the special Munch exhibit.

If you are a fan of Modern Art this is one of the finest in the world. The extensive renovation and additional space has transformed a wonderful space into one that can better showcase their permanent collection (now enhanced by their partnership with the Fisher family collection) and still have adequate space for special exhibitions (presently a wonderful presentation of about 50 of Edvard Munch paintings). The docents are exceptional and they are trying out a new method using headsets so that the distractions of others in the museum don't disrupt the docent leading the discussion. many of the docents like to get the group involved making for an interactive as well as educational time. Especially with modern art, everyone has their own opinion and that variety enhances the experience. The cafe is pretty much the same (didn't go this time) and the outdoor sculpture garden (a magical place) was being renovated. The only downside to the new facility was the signage especially between the new upper floors (six and seven), the bridge, and the new areas. Without the paper "map" one could end up wasting time going back and forth.
